jurisdiction.title: Roman Catholic Diocese of Joliet Illinois

858C9BADFA5E4059BB0C5BBEB42DC2E4.description:
MS-ETS1-4. Develop a model to generate data for iterative testing and modification of a proposed object, tool, or process such that an optimal
design can be achieved.

9EF1ABD29A014FE198D9C217A7CCAAF9.description:
MS-ETS1-3. Analyze data from tests to determine similarities and differences among several design solutions to identify the best characteristics of
each that can be combined into a new solution to better meet the criteria for success.

A2F21BC0621D4CFB99989AB84447883A.description:
MS-ETS1-2. Evaluate competing design solutions using a systematic process to determine how well they meet the criteria and constraints of the
problem

367271FFAC6945309E2C341192630DC7.description:
MS-ETS1-1. Define the criteria and constraints of a design problem with sufficient precision to ensure a successful solution, taking into account
relevant scientific principles and potential impacts on people and the natural environment that may limit possible solutions

EF38A0F9E69D4B99B137FC9BDCDA8F40.description:
CSIS8: Investigate how science properly limits its focus to how things physically exist and is not designed to answer issues of the meaning,
the value of things, or the mysteries of the human person.

7EB7ABD4AF044DB292DBAB7B25BB894B.description:
CSIS7: Describe how science and technology should always be at the service of humanity, and ultimately, to God in harmony with His
purposes

CE956A12B00346EBAFD7D338037FCBCA.description: CSDS3: Adhere to the idea simultaneous complexity and simplicity of physical reality.

7BE0520D479C41C2B6C345267499BE9F.description:
CSIS9: Distinguish the difference between the use of the scientific method (as the primary cause) and the use of theological inquiry (as the secondary
cause) to know and understand God’s creation and universal truth.

8BFA1252B01C427AAF8AEEE761E21A1D.description:
MS-PS4-3. Integrate qualitative scientific and technical information to support the claim that digitized signals are a more reliable way to encode
and transmit information than analog signals.

5F501431BF694376ACD2928AD91CE667.description: MS-PS4-2. Develop and use a model to describe that waves are reflected, absorbed, or transmitted through various materials

29506C6330F7490D83D8AAD5FA554FBC.description:
MS-PS4-1. Use mathematical representations to describe a simple model for waves that includes how the amplitude of a wave is related to the
energy in a wave.

9F06227AC47641CA943E3AD50F12A5E8.description: Waves and Their Applications in Technologies for Information Transfer

7ABB1746E3664104BD34F9381945460C.description:
MS-PS3-5. Construct, use, and present arguments to support the claim that when the kinetic energy of an object changes, energy is transferred to
or from the object.

89DB98699A40402C8D47605BEC84C7E4.description:
MS-PS3-4. Plan an investigation to determine the relationships among the energy transferred, the type of matter, the mass, and the change in the
average kinetic energy of the particles as measured by the temperature of the sample.

92E459BB460A43CC9BDC2F8E8530C3F9.description: MS-PS3-3. Apply scientific principles to design, construct, and test a device that either minimizes or maximizes thermal energy transfer.

3442A46CC6CA4EA9BFB15D60A762FE78.description:
MS-PS3-2. Develop a model to describe that when the arrangement of objects interacting at a distance changes, different amounts of potential
energy are stored in the system.

D81630DC94A24CDBB9F76ACE05F0AD64.description:
MS-PS3-1. Construct and interpret graphical displays of data to describe the relationships of kinetic energy to the mass of an object and to the
speed of an object.

41AD4340BD094E459C062CD42A62E51F.description:
MS-PS2-5. Conduct an investigation and evaluate the experimental design to provide evidence that fields exist between objects exerting forces on
each other even though the objects are not in contact.

DAE5DB13AEE74E55B128E44C43DBF9DF.description:
MS-PS2-4. Construct and present arguments using evidence to support the claim that gravitational interactions are attractive and depend on the
masses of interacting objects.

0B64E65FC38B4BB8870DDAA1BE72AD66.description: MS-PS2-3. Ask questions about data to determine the factors that affect the strength of electric and magnetic forces.

3AADFAD052694DE68268285C79A00197.description:
MS-PS2-2. Plan an investigation to provide evidence that the change in an object’s motion depends on the sum of the forces on the object and the
mass of the object.

9D013B1BBBE34C8A852E688A9E7450A8.description: MS-PS2-1. Apply Newton’s Third Law to design a solution to a problem involving the motion of two colliding objects.

6B8C0E3C36854658A16E4A502A6EBD05.description: Motion and Stability: Forces and Interactions

FA922A2492D44113BF95B08264CCD1E9.description: MS-PS1-6. Undertake a design project to construct, test, and modify a device that either releases or absorbs thermal energy by chemical processes.

C757B3E899B5473D927CA48194C9F20B.description:
MS-PS1-5. Develop and use a model to describe how the total number of atoms does not change in a chemical reaction and thus mass is
conserved.

7623E76685CF4DFC86DD6D06B30B457E.description:
MS-PS1-4. Develop a model that predicts and describes changes in particle motion, temperature, and state of a pure substance when thermal
energy is added or removed.

250414E0ADD44D05B676B2409DAAF2C9.description: MS-PS1-3. Gather and make sense of information to describe that synthetic materials come from natural resources and impact society.

BE8E8C96819C43F885C48C999E73AB77.description:
MS-PS1-2. Analyze and interpret data on the properties of substances before and after the substances interact to determine if a chemical reaction
has occurred.

574428DC630A4B7BA7D93B37D3A540C8.description: MS-PS1-1. Develop models to describe the atomic composition of simple molecules and extended structures.

BBCB1379CEE24B80B80EAB94BB5F2CDE.description: MS-ESS3-5. Ask questions to clarify evidence of the factors that have caused the rise in global temperatures over the past century.

CA10181D02EF4641ACAE6993F010E115.description:
MS-ESS3-4. Construct an argument supported by evidence for how increases in human population and per-capita consumption of natural
resources impact Earth's systems.

63605EC1E3424BB39A478106E58CDF3A.description: MS-ESS3-3. Apply scientific principles to design a method for monitoring and minimizing a human impact on the environment.

1AE70C70ED194D62A5846D1555029631.description:
MS-ESS3-2. Analyze and interpret data on natural hazards to forecast future catastrophic events and inform the development of technologies to
mitigate their effects.

41508F81DDBB42C0BE57C74C2B5A7562.description:
MS-ESS3-1. Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for how the uneven distributions of Earth's mineral, energy, and groundwater
resources are the result of past and current geosciences processes.

22E9AD8C0D084A71A4143233E967F1E9.description: CSAD4: Value and care for the environment as part of God’s creation.

BEF87FB17D3C41FD914A75804DACBD23.description:
CSIS5: Discuss processes of conservation, preservation, over consumption, and stewardship of creation as caring for that which
 God has given us to sustain us.

A9F769ACC98546BD953B6F6497F481A6.description:
MS-ESS2-6. Develop and use a model to describe how unequal heating and rotation of the Earth cause patterns of atmospheric and oceanic
circulation that determine regional climates.

EFCCFE97EA2E4FEDB1DB61EFD32BF446.description: MS-ESS2-5. Collect data to provide evidence for how the motions and complex interactions of air masses results in changes in weather conditions.

CF8B6BFC0A074ED0BF633C0281889720.description: MS-ESS2-4. Develop a model to describe the cycling of water through Earth's systems driven by energy from the sun and the force of gravity.

0CDBB8DD06904AA6BE58B5A162F74BC0.description:
MS-ESS2-3. Analyze and interpret data on the distribution of fossils and rocks, continental shapes, and seafloor structures to provide evidence of
the past plate motions.

F8A90284C214455DA4D8B47C5F72C500.description:
MS-ESS2-2. Construct an explanation based on evidence for how geoscience processes have changed Earth's surface at varying time and spatial
scales.

E278ACBE6E824115A09625E3E8982A3E.description: MS-ESS2-1. Develop a model to describe the cycling of Earth's materials and the flow of energy that drives this process.

B7C515E1E7254C82BC3A96FF74E44A77.description: CSIS2: Describe the relationships, elements, underlying order, harmony, and meaning in God’s creation.

E41AED19569045C2880B26EE75240476.description:
MS-ESS1-4. Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence from rock strata for how the geologic time scale is used to organize Earth's 4.6-
billion-year-old history.

16F99EAF08654B5CBF322EC82C230F2A.description: MS-ESS1-3. Analyze and interpret data to determine scale properties of objects in the solar system.

80340EF762A94325865A7542B537C7CD.description: MS-ESS1-2. Develop and use a model to describe the role of gravity in the motions within galaxies and the solar system.

4A8698C366C84503994DAE9331B650C2.description:
MS-ESS1-1. Develop and use a model of the Earth-sun-moon system to describe the cyclic patterns of lunar phases, eclipses of the sun and moon,
and seasons.

982F0F05097646AF8EA1227652175E55.description: CSIS6: Discuss the relationship between God, man, and nature, and one’s proper role in the totality of being and creation.

2C7069AD865D4048BEC80F0923CE54C6.description:
MS-LS4-6. Use mathematical representations to support explanations of how natural selection may lead to increases and decreases of specific
traits in populations over time.

8834E65B48CC4892BCF233FAC5DCA2C4.description:
MS-LS4-5. Gather and synthesize information about the technologies that have changed the way humans influence the inheritance of desired traits
in organisms.

6F916D85AB624738998CA2E2063D1AB4.description:
MS-LS4-4. Construct an explanation based on evidence that describes how genetic variations of traits in a population increase some individuals’
probability of surviving and reproducing in a specific environment.

088147DA1D5D417282316537DA617A0E.description:
MS-LS4-3. Analyze displays of pictorial data to compare patterns of similarities in the embryological development across multiple species to
identify relationships not evident in the fully formed anatomy.

7F0408E4AE2B4930A5BCC54DC8FEF88C.description:
MS-LS4-2. Apply scientific ideas to construct an explanation for the anatomical similarities and differences among modern organisms and between
modern and fossil organisms to infer evolutionary relationships.

53072B78FEF44A38B0F0F9646E6028C4.description:
MS-LS4-1. Analyze and interpret data for patterns in the fossil record that document the existence, diversity, extinction, and change of life forms
throughout the history of life on Earth under the assumption that natural laws operate today as in the past.

25D11E844C7D4420893369DFE85BA2EA.description:
CSIS13: Discuss how the human soul is specifically created by God for each human being and does not evolve from lesser matter, nor is it inherited
from our parents.

F3BB24D1B35441BDA4CD5BF298B01976.description: CSIS12: Examine and discuss the Church’s approach to the theory of evolution.

71F58BCDB89249FD8592ED8C51CC6A12.description:
MS-LS3-2. Develop and use a model to describe why asexual reproduction results in offspring with identical genetic information and sexual
reproduction results in offspring with genetic variation.

6462565AD8DE48798657F3F8D9040023.description:
MS-LS3-1. Develop and use a model to describe why structural changes to genes (mutations) located on chromosomes may affect proteins and
may result in harmful, beneficial, or neutral effects to the structure and function of the organism.

FC693CF1FF1C4F98ADB60C863B5DB77D.description:
CSIS17: Demonstrate an understanding of the moral issues involving cellular research and human experimentation and what the Church teaches
regarding work in these areas.

5CC23C17AF624C568F5206B9B6CFC807.description: CSIS7: Describe humanity’s natural situation in, and dependence upon, physical reality and how we carry out our role as a cooperator with God.

85E2D8DD85D04EBBA312E7747F92AB23.description: CSIS6: Discuss the relationship between God, man, and nature, and one’s proper role in the totality of being and creation.

21D92BA033CC436EB3CCB6C3D9707BD0.description: Heredity: Inheritance and Variation of Traits

ACC02B5C5EFD4C4CA6A12ADD806C2E73.description: MS-LS2-5. Evaluate competing design solutions for maintaining biodiversity and ecosystem services.

B48D644515FE4AC6A34429E740BF6C3A.description:
MS-LS2-4. Construct an argument supported by empirical evidence that changes to physical or biological components of an ecosystem affect
populations.

860B0078330048CFB638BAA08C8B0E4B.description: MS-LS2-3. Develop a model to describe the cycling of matter and flow of energy among living and nonliving parts of an ecosystem.

09C5BCD7E6D44ED193A713A74E8236DC.description: MS-LS2-2. Construct an explanation that predicts patterns of interactions among organisms across multiple ecosystems.

4CF402E9D11B47C3B44372A4DF3AF54D.description:
MS-LS2-1. Analyze and interpret data to provide evidence for the effects of resource availability on organisms and populations of organisms in an
ecosystem.

FB692EC26426464EB984A4971B572D50.description:
CSIS5: Discuss processes of conservation, preservation, overconsumption and stewardship of creation as caring for that which God has given us to
sustain us.

4E163CF2CDB64985ACC47541320B05E9.description: CSIS2: Describe the relationships, elements, underlying order, harmony, and meaning in God’s creation.

AA0DA32F59E447379A907BB9AD3DCA21.description:
MS-LS1-8. Gather and synthesize information that sensory receptors respond to stimuli by sending messages to the brain for immediate behavior
or storage as memories.

481F65E7E18A43558308A27AEF0E47EC.description:
MS-LS1-7. Develop a model to describe how food is rearranged through chemical reactions forming new molecules that support growth and/or
release energy as this matter moves through an organism.

9576222E43B04739837E3460862A82F5.description:
MS-LS1-6. Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for the role of photosynthesis in the cycling of matter and flow of energy into and
out of organisms.

D187CE42A7AA46069A3E6BC91DB18035.description: MS-LS1-5. Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for how environmental and genetic factors influence the growth of organisms.

36C75E23EE7945C881B060483AE4E557.description:
MS-LS1-4. Use argument based on empirical evidence and scientific reasoning to support an explanation for how characteristic animal behaviors
and specialized plant structures affect the probability of successful reproduction of animals and plants respectively.

F8D33ADABE514A2CA97B26A44DFBEA58.description: MS-LS1-3. Use argument supported by evidence for how the body is a system of interacting subsystems composed of groups of cells.

EBBB7B61F2574ADE81DFEEAB9A215F32.description: MS-LS1-2. Develop and use a model to describe the function of a cell as a whole and ways parts of cells contribute to the function.

1680E88891B24348BAB0DBCF6F3A9C43.description:
MS-LS1-1. Conduct an investigation to provide evidence that living things are made of cells; either one cell or many different numbers and types of
cells.

929D6B2079A5490189C037E2714DEEEB.description:
CSIS10: Understand and discuss the limitations of science (the scientific method and constraints of the physical world) to know and understand
God.

733899046BCD4863B360DD4CA5E0815B.description:
CSIS4: Discuss how the search for truth, even when it concerns a finite reality of the natural world or of man, is never-ending, but always points
beyond to something higher.

948B20D65D4F4C7281B2CD37A9BE9CC4.description: CSIS2: Display confidence in human reason and in one’s ability to know the truth about God creation.

76DABCD508494D8786312D369C8670D4.description: From Molecules to Organisms: Structures and Processes
